title: 104_hr2285
content: The Theodore Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act is introduced by Congress to fund conservation efforts through the sale of collectors' coins. Theodore Roosevelt's conservation efforts are highlighted as inspiration for natural resource conservation in the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The Secretary is authorized to issue gold coins with specific dates and amounts under section 5112(b) of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary is authorized to issue silver coins with specific dates and amounts, not exceeding 500,000 in 1997 and 1998. The Secretary shall issue clad coins with specific dates and amounts not exceeding 1,000,000 in 1997 and 1998. The coins minted under this Act in 1997 and 1998 will not exceed 1,000,000 and 1,250,000 respectively. These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting coins from existing sources, and silver only from stockpiles established under a specific Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. Design Requirements for the coins minted under this Act include the likeness of Theodore Roosevelt on the obverse side and an emblematic representation of the Nation's natural resources on the reverse side. Each coin must also include a value designation, date inscription, and the words "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts. The design for the coins minted under this Act must include Theodore Roosevelt on the obverse side and a representation of natural resources on the reverse side. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 1997, with minting authority ending on December 31, 1998. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will be included in all sales. The coins issued under this Act will be sold at prices of $35 for the $5 coin, $7 for the $1 coin, and $2 for the half dollar coin. Bulk sales and prepaid orders will receive discounts, with surcharges included in all sales. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for Act implementation, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges for coins sold under the Act. SEC. 8 of the Act outlines the distribution of surcharges from coin sales to support the administration of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. Any excess surcharges will be deposited into the general fund of the Treasury. SEC. 9 addresses financial assurances. SEC. 9 of the Act ensures that minting and issuing coins will not cost the government. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantees.
